item.title: Chalk Talks and Plots
item.description:
The past few days I was at the Utah Math Bio Alumni Conference. It was great being back at my alma mater surrounded by so many talented mathematicians and scientists, but more on that next week when I’ll write about my conference experience (I’ll also be at SMB this week). What I want to write about today are some thoughts I’ve had on chalk talks. Prior to their talks a lot of presenters took a few minutes to reminisce about their experiences with Utah math bio. The quality of physiology group meetings came up several times. At one point, someone (I think it was Eric Cytrynbaum) mentioned how it was difficult nowadays to get students to use the board during group meetings when everyone has a laptop and uses powerpoints and computer-generated plots. That got me thinking and wondering when I’ve had my last “real” chalk talk. And it’s been a while. It’s definitely true in my experience that we’ve become very reliant on powerpoints and beamer presentations. And I have to say I miss chalk talks. When I was a senior at Utah I took an intro to applied math course with Dr. Cherkaev that required us to present a final project on a topic of our choosing. I remember being the only one in the course not using a powerpoint.

I like chalk talks and I think being good at chalk talks is a great skill to have. And it’s especially important for graduate students. We don’t have a lot of papers out yet, with us being early in our career and all. But we have ideas and enthusiasm. Actively writing your work down while you discuss it with peers is a great way to communicate that enthusiasm. And this is frankly one area where I feel that pure math students tend to have a leg up on applied students. Or at least the one’s I know. One-on-one meetings with their advisors tend to involve blackboard work or going over handwritten pages. Applied students? Open your laptop, show some code and or graphs, what have you. Not that there is anything wrong with that. It just leads to us having less practice.

One of the appeals of computer aided presentation is that we can use graphs and images. In science we often have cool images and nice graphs and we love showing them off. But whether or not it is important to show someone these particular visuals depends on what we’re trying to accomplish. I’m not arguing we should do chalk talks at conference presentations. I’m thinking more of informal settings such as lab meetings or just getting together with peers in the department lounge. In such informal situations, what I am generally trying to accomplish is give my peers a high level overview of what I’m currently doing, what challenges I may face and what results I got. And if I have plots, I don’t expect them to notice anything very precise. In general I’m trying to point out some qualitative behavior of interest. And that frankly does not require me firing up matplotlib or a draft of a paper I’m writing. Qualitative behavior lends itself to back-of-the-envelope plotting.

XKCD is a great example of just how effectivey seemingly “crude” plots and charts can be. Here is an example:

It gets the point across. Humor in this case, but the same can be done with research. I’m sure most of us have done it at some point; perhaps at a bar on a napkin with their peers after a conference. And it’s exciting and fun. I feel it draws the audience in more than searching through your phone for some nice plot you made. Doing this type of presentation more often would be refreshing.

item.title: MeshmerizeMe: A Tool for the Creation of Curvilinear Meshes for Immersed Boundary Simulations
IBM Geometry Creation
item.description:
Summary

IB2d and IBAMR are two software packages implementing the immersed boundary method (see below). These packages model fluid-structure interaction problems based on user given parameters and geometry. The manual creation of the initial geometry mesh can be difficult and time consuming, especially for the complex shapes encountered in biological applications. Oftentimes we have images of the geometry we wish to explore. I am developing software to help automate the creation of such CFD meshes for 2D simulations with a file-format suitable for use with IB2d and IBAMR from images. An initial prototype version is available on Github. A paper exploring the use of MeshmerizeMe in conjuction with IB2d for simulations is in preparation.

Usage

MeshmerizeMe needs two input files per experimental geometry: an SVG image file with the geometry of interest and an input2d file with the experiment parameters. When selecting an SVG for use with MeshmerizeMe it will automatically look for the input2d file in the same folder. It will then parse the paths, transform them into the correct coordinate system and appropriately sample the paths based on the size of the Cartesian grid set in the input2d file. The geometry will be exported as a vertex file. This file is readable by both IB2d and IBAMR.

SVGs were chosen as the image source as the are an open, text-based format making them very accesible to work with. They are standardized for web use and many tools exist for creating and manipulating SVG images. They can be created from source images such as photographs or scans by means of edge detection tools and by manually tracing the outline of a shape of interest Consider optimizing the SVG prior to processing to save time.

As the current version of MeshmerizeMe only handles a subset of SVG, tools that optimize the SVG files created by your editor are very useful. Examples of such software include SVGO, which also offers a webapp called SVGOMG. Another software is svgcleaner.

IBM Background

One aspect of computational fluid dynamics is the investigation of
fluid-structure interactions. One method developed for the study of such interactions is the immersed boundary method (IBM) developed by Peskin1. It is well known that fluids can be studied from both a Eulerian and a Lagrangian view. The IBM combines these - the domain of the problem is resolved as a Cartesian grid on which Eulerian equations are solved for fluid velocity and pressure. In the case of Newtonian fluids the incompressible Navier-Stokes equations comprising of

$$ \rho \left( \frac{\partial \mathbf{u}}{\partial t} + \mathbf{u} \cdot \nabla \mathbf{u} \right) = - \nabla \mathbf{p} + \mu \nabla^2 \mathbf{u} + \mathbf{f}$$

and

$$\nabla \cdot \mathbf{u} = 0$$

need to be solved.

The immersed structures are modeled as fibers in the form of parametric curves $X(s,t)$, where $s$ is a parameter and $t$ is time. The fiber experiences force distributions $F(s,t)$, and we can derive the force the fiber exerts on the fluid from the momentum equation. For the fibers we then solve

$$\mathbf{f} = \int_\Gamma \mathbf{F}(s,t)\,\delta\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{X}(s,t)\right)\,ds$$

and

$$\frac{\partial \mathbf{X}}{\partial t} = \int_\Omega \mathbf{u}(\mathbf{x},t)\, \delta \left( \mathbf{x}-\mathbf{X}(s,t)\right)\,d\mathbf{x}.$$

Here, $\Gamma$ is the immersed structure and $\Omega$ is the fluid domain.

The immersed structures are discretized not on a Cartesian grid but on a separate Lagrangian grid on the fiber itself. Of import to CFD software users is that the initial discretization of the immersed structure has to be supplied by the user. While this is not too difficult for simple geometries, the often complex structures encountered in mathematical biology can present a significant time investment. This is the part where MeshmerizeMe comes in handy.

  1. Charles S Peskin. 2002. “The immersed boundary method.” Acta numerica 11:479-517. ^

item.title: Filming Thrips with Vishwa
item.description:
This past month has been rather exciting due to a visit by OSU graduate student Vishwa Teja Kasoju. He is a student in the Mechanical & Aerospace engineering PhD program as part of Dr. Santhanakrishnan’s lab.

Vishwa visited both UNC and Duke to get some footage of thrips flight and Mantis shrimp escape behaviors. My undergraduate student Kristen Armel and I assisted Vishwa in some of his thrips collecting and filming. It was a good learning experience for us, as we learned how to work with the high speed cameras we have on-site. We had good luck finding thrips around campus, escpecially a day after it rained. Luckily there were plenty of rainy days in June, so we had no shortage of specimen.

item.title: Tiny Insect Flight
item.description:
Winged insects are taxonomically diverse and inhabit virtually every terrestrial ecosystem on our planet. They range in size from the most minute insects, barely visible to the naked eye, to those with wingspans greater than 7 inches - larger than the palm of an adult human! With such diversity, insects provide a plethora of model organisms for investigating flight.

Students of biology are familiar with the fact that small bacteria tend to move differently than fish swim for example. This is because a swimming motion is not effective in moving you forward when you’re as small as a bacterium. But flagella and celia will in fact move you forward effectively at that size. This difference in behavior has to do with how the organism in question experiences the relative effects of inertial and viscous forces. One way of quantifying the relative importance of these effects is with the dimensionless quantity known as the Reynolds number; it is given by $$\mathrm{Re}= \frac{\rho u L}{\mu},$$ where $\rho$ is the density of the fluid1 in which the organism is moving, $u$ is the velocity of the fluid with respect to the organism, $L$ is the “characteristic length” of the organism, and $\mu$ is the dynamic viscosity of the fluid. We and many of the animals that we are familiar with from every day life live in a “high Reynolds number world.” When we say high, we mean a value of Re in the thousands and tens of thousands and higher. Bacteria on the other hand live in a low Reynolds number world, with values on the order of $\mathrm{Re} \ll 1$. The intermediate Reynolds number world is less well studied, and that’s where some interesting stuff happens!

Very small insects, such as thrips and fairyflies, live in the intermediate Reynolds number world. While larger insects typically create lift by creating a leading edge vortex that remains attached to their wings, while a trailing edge vortex is created and shed from the wing with each stroke. The tiny insects on the other hand shed neither their trailing nor leading edge vortices, and instead engage in what is known as clap-and-fling (cf. here for some details). Another interesting aspect of the flight of the smallest fliers is that their wings show interesting adaptations. Most of us are familiar with the way bee wings look. Even fruitflies have a very similar wing structure. Very tiny fliers on the other hand will have relatively small wings with large bristles attached to them, as in the image below.

When gathering footage for previous work on clap-and-fling (Santhanakrishnan et al, 2014), we also happened to come across footage showing parachuting behavior. Active flight is energetically costly, especially if you want to go far. Passive flight behaviors are an integral part of long-distance travel; just think of large birds you may see circling on convection currents in the air. My work is on trying to understand the aerodynamics of such passive flight behaviors in tiny insects.

  1. Mathematically, we can treat air as a fluid. ^
